feed.title: Sam Kenney
feed.subtitle: Portfolio website and blog for myself.

entry.title: CLI Note taking application
entry.content:
For the longest time, I’ve been using sticky notes to document anything important. But let’s be honest, it’s great for noting down a quick reminder, but maybe not so much for writing down the requirements for the latest dashboard you need to develop.


I’m a big advocate of Vim, and love the simplicity of a CLI, so I thought to myself: why not write a CLI-based notes app.


So that’s exactly what I did.


Some screenshots of the app in use.


You can check out the source code here if you’d like to give it a go yourself.
entry.summary: For the longest time, I’ve been using sticky notes to document anything important. But let’s be honest, it’s great for noting down a quick reminder, but maybe not so much for writing down the requirements for the latest dashboard you need to develop.

entry.title: Tracking a face using Python and an Arduino UNO

link.title: Tracking a face using Python and an Arduino UNO

entry.content:
Computer vision is a subject that has always interested me. From a workplace perspective, I thought about being able to read contracts and extract data from them to use in some of our automated processes.


However, I couldn’t get the sign off to spend time doing that, so I thought the next best thing would be to build something for myself.


So, I invested in an Arduino starter kit and decided to make a webcam that will follow my face as I move around.


To do this, I needed to learn some of the Open CV Python library, as well as some basic C++ in order to interface with the Arduino itself.


Some images / videos here


As always, you can find the source code for the project here.
entry.summary: Computer vision is a subject that has always interested me. From a workplace perspective, I thought about being able to read contracts and extract data from them to use in some of our automated processes.

entry.title: What Comes Next?
entry.content:
What Comes Next? was the debut album for the band Worst Case Scenario.

On this album, I wrote a number of the song’s instrumentals including Stalemate, A Monument To Your Sins, Chasms, and Sun & Moon.

I also contributed a significant amount to the instrumentals of Terrorist Synthesiser, and It’s Always Sunny In February.
entry.summary: What Comes Next? was the debut album for the band Worst Case Scenario. On this album, I wrote a number of the song’s instrumentals including Stalemate, A Monument To Your Sins, Chasms, and Sun & Moon. I also contributed a significant amount to the instrumentals of Terrorist Synthesiser, and It’s Always Sunny In February.
